text: hi everybody
pretty excited Anthony Fantino here
Internet's busiest music nerd oh and
it's time for a review the Mars Volta
not tourniquet the Mars Volta is a Texas
progressive rock band that rose out of
the ashes of a group that I like a
little bit more at the drive-in but you
know despite the initial loss of at the
drive-in the band's core members did go
on to do bigger things in the Mars Volta
they became major players in the world
of modern progressive rock and not just
like you know copycat progressive rock
that just sounds like old-school
progressive rock I'm talking about like
the new modern futuristic face of
progressive rock and infusing it with
ideas from the world of post-hardcore
among other things but I was kind of
hesitant to review this LP for a second
it is my first mars volta review it kind
of comes off the heels of one of Mars
Voltas LPS that is not considered to be
one of their best and if you're a
hardcore fan I'm sure you remember last
year Mars Volta had a bit of a struggle
with their label to release this thing
and you know Warner Brothers their kind
of label that I'm sure is heavily
heavily interested in the bottom line
and I'm sure they don't want to release
another record that's going to
disappoint fans especially since a lot
of people are not happy with the the
simpler more straightforward approach
that octahedron put out there Cedric
went as far as to call this the band's
pop record I think that's maybe taking
things a little too far but this LP does
kind of hang
in that same accessible territory there
aren't really any hard-edged lengthy
dense Frances the mute style guitar jams
on this thing this is definitely not the
kind of blood-pumping teeth-gnashing
high octane power that would make me
afraid to listen on headphones I fear
that my brain would just explode load
load loads and just pour out of my ear
canals Nocturna key is definitely a
little toned down in comparison with
some mars volta albums but the band is
making a conscious effort to replace
that volume that intensity that lengthy
Jam style with some new sounds some
experimentation some accessibility and
some really beautiful melodies too as
much as the band has changed clearly
they're still kind of staying true to
their roots of being a band that puts
together really sound rich rock music
but I think they're taking that to the
next level and you can even catch that
on the opening track the whip ant where
Cedric's vocals are just slathered in
weird mutant chorus effects there's some
really bright loud synthesizers
overpowering the track and they're just
these little sonic nuggets all
throughout the album on this track it
kind of comes up in a spot where cedric
is is kind of doing this lone screaming
spoken word part but you hear all these
vocals kind of yelling in the background
just creating this layer of hectic noise
underneath him the track dyslexic on is
also really liberal with the
synthesizers there since on here that
our sputtering that our squawking that
are really kind of glassy glassy and
just putting a nice smooth finish on the
track and Cedric is just in the middle
of all this synthetic noise the
synthetic cacophony and even though the
band isn't really embarking on a
traditional Mars Volta Jam the track
still it's a really great groove the
malkin jewel the first single off of
this LP starts off with a real
nice bluesy guitar riff this kind of
banjo that has a totally different
recording quality to it is just
twiddling away in the background the
guitar has a really nice bouncy reverb
too in the way Cedric is singing it just
kind of reminds me of like a White
Stripes track or something but in a good
way and what I like about the track is
that it just gets progressively more
intense as it goes along more noises
kind of coming in layering on top of one
another
drums start getting really intense
filling in every open space the
synthesizers which kind of have this
organ quality to them are playing some
really sinister chords these sci-fi
keyboards are just screaming in the
right channel and it is just so
overpowering I think I think my favorite
track on here though might be the song
Aegis one of the slower songs on here
the second track it opens up with this
guitar guitar chord progression that is
really nasty really dark stuff and for
some reason on this track Cedric's
falsetto vocal when he when he reaches
those highs on this song it just has
this really kind of futuristic
otherworldly vibe to it that I like and
when he's singing about children being
seen and I heard strikes me as being
really kind of twisted the hook on this
track comes crashing through like a
drunk driver through the brick wall of
the building where he's supposed to be
having his next a a meeting and like I
said this track in this album is not
really indulgent like other mars volta
LPS but the band is usually pretty good
pretty consistent when it comes to
writing hooks that just soar that just
explode huge hooks and this album is no
different because when Cedric's vocals
just reach the highs on this song they
fly it's just pure ecstacy ZZ but it's
not long before I'm kind of getting into
some tracks that I guess I'm not totally
feeling the song empty vessels has some
really light feathery vocals from Cedric
that just feel to kind of sugary to me
and it's lyrics about forgiving your
your broken heart
sometimes I'm really not totally into
lyrics on this album the song in
absentia presents way more effects than
any other song on here I would say the
song is almost completely carried by
effects because the tune itself drums
this vocal melody some guitar that I can
kind of make out I think it's all hidden
behind this really opaque and and muddy
mix and it's intentionally muddy and
slathered and reverb and just kind of
obscured kind of hidden and while it is
an interesting sound for a while it's
for some reason the longest song on this
LP I wish the band would have kind of
drawn out another track on this LP
instead even as a soundscape I'm really
not in love with this track especially
since a lot of the effects cédric uses
on this vocals on on this one kind of
grate on my ears but those are really
the only tracks on here where I'm really
not into the textures that Volta is
using in their songs for the most part
this thing is just loaded with really
really colorful rock songs rock songs
that despite how many changes this band
is made to its formula on this thing
still display a decent amount of guts
the song MalK walker and in my opinion
brings that usual jam level intensity of
this band but in kind of a pared down 3
minute and 31 second package and their
moments on here where I'm hearing
reverse drums reverse guitar solos found
sound of like a crowd talking but I do
want to emphasize that I think Mars
Volta is still writing good Tunes though
this six studio LP of theirs is
definitely heavily heavily indebted to
synthesizers effects the band is really
trying to explore sound a bit more and I
like it the tracks on this thing are as
composed of chords and notes as they are
textures and and futuristic synthetics
and while this thing is definitely one
of the most instantaneous and accessible
records yet they've still layers so
any sounds into this thing you can
return to and return to and return to it
and still kind of pick up little layers
that you might not have heard before
there are a lot of subtleties in this
mix and despite all the positive things
I could say about this album there's
still no way this thing is going to
become a universal fan pleaser because
it's nowhere near as intense as some of
Marv's Voltas earlier records and the
gorgeous moments that this album does
present are not plentiful enough to make
even me kind of forget that and totally
fall in love with this newer
straightforward direction still I think
with this record Mars Volta is on the
cusp of something really interesting a
really awesome hybrid of of experimental
sounds and progressive rock and whether
they're making songs that are accessible
and catchy or long-winded and difficult
that is a road I would like to see them
continue down the album is pretty solid
throughout starts off with some really
great tracks and finishes with a
fantastic one-two
zette into knots one of the coolest
songs I think these guys have written so
far
basically I'm feeling a decent too
strong seven on this thing thought it
was really good but what do you guys
think of it do you love it do you hate
it why and what should I review next
anthony Fantana
